div.p: A Continuation of The Journal of the Forks MacKenzie's River for Summer 1807[.]

August Friday 1st[.] Found many articles belonging to both the Shop and Store missing – which Martin tells me were taken per Mr Alexr MacKenzie, who left however no account of his having employed them[.] The Goods were Amn HWines Dressed moose deer Skins & Orignal Snares[.] This nevertheless not a little perplexes me, as I don't know whether I should trust to this report or consider it as an excuse of the old Fellows to clear himself from reproaches of extravagance – of which however I must confess I cannot accuse him[.] More true Statements of expences can be kept at a post when such means are adopted to supply wants and exigencies, are best known to those Gentlemen who practice these Short methods of arranging themselves at the expence of other Posts[.] Yet Mr McK. is perhaps the severest of any in finding faults with all accounts except his own – Tho he himself is the first to put the example of trangressing his own rules[.] But […] by […]

Satury 2nd[.] Early in the morning Mr Clarke with two Canadians and Indian embarked in a large Canoe ladened 23 Packs, 4 ps Dried meat his own Bag & baggage for Athabasca[.] [R]ained in the afternoon[.]
Suny 3rd[.] Rained at intervals all Day[.]
Mony 4th[.] As I am to be left by Smiths departure to Mr Keith's without a Small Canoe to fish with, I Sent him to raise Maitres for a Seaulteux Canoe[.]

Tuesy 5th[.] [R]ainy weather[.] Four Indians arrived very Sick of a distemper they had caught by eating the Flesh of a dead Animal they found in the woods, which I suppose died of some disease – as great numbers are found all over Some unable to rise themselves upon their legs and others dead[.] [W]hether this Sickness in the Animal species is owing to the Dryness of the Season or the occasioned by the great Fires which have almost overrun the whole Country I cannot tell[.] The consequences appear already by the removal of the Indians to the Great Willow & Porcupi[ne] Lakes for subsistance – they being unable to find food elsewhere, Th[ese]
